Another advantage our eyes have over most video sensors is the arrangement of the 'pixels' in the eye isn't regular but instead has been shown to be optimal to avoid the problems video cameras often have with regular patterns - pin-striped suits, picket fences, zebras and such often demonstrate the video camera's limitations. The eye's solution to sampling problems isn't perfect and this may partly explain the zebra strips as their density can generate distracting illusions to confuse lions.

Your brain also has SUPER compression. You could show someone a tree with just a few branches, and they will think they remember it perfectly, but if you ask them to draw the lowest branch on the tree, what they draw will not be what it looks like, because your brain doesn't save the pixels, it saves the parts of the image, and that is why you can imagine moving around a memory where an object was once obstructed, your bran will just try to make that object if it knows what it is, even if it has never seen that part of it. That is also why you can just think of any table but it is more or less impossible to "see" all the little details, and as you continue to imagine it, the textures on the table can seamlessly change when you imagine looking away because your brain stores the table in memory, but not the textures, unless you specifically imagine part of the texture.

In fact, the “resolution of the human eye“, or, “how many megapixels it has“ is quite well known to printers, you can assume a value of about 12 - 18 megapixels, a fact which you can check yourself. Just print out very small letters with a very good printer, and you will realize that the eye can identify structures of about one tenth of a millimeter. Then check out the distance on which you see this structures. Then take a piece of paper and check which paper size fills your field of vision. If you take that area × the resolution, you will end up with about 12 - 18 “megapixels“, which would be the upper limit of all the “pixels“ you can see with “full resolution“ at once. You might have just asked a printer for that information. Thank you for your attention.

As someone with damaged retinas (scar tissue from several retinal surgeries), I’m well aware of how the brain fills in blank spots with what it thinks should be there.  When I look at small print, I’ll often see words differently than what is actually printed.  Some letters will fall into one of my blank spots, and my brain will fill in the blank with letters it thinks should be there.  If I glance away and look back, I’ll see a different word.  It’s very freaky, although I’ve gotten used to it.  My biggest problem is with numbers, because my brain can’t fill in blank spots with characters that fit into the context, so I can almost never trust what I’m seeing when I look at numbers.

I found a way to see the lack of color at the sides of your vision.

Want to know the resolution of the human eye?  Try this.  Go outside on a clear night, place your hand over one eye, and use your other eye to look up at the night sky.  As you know those little dots of light are from stars that are many light years away.  The size of each dot of light is the size of a rod in your eye that receives the light.  This size tells you the lower limit of your eye's vision and, thus, your eye's resolution.

If VSause replies to this, I will freak out. I did the Calculations myuself, using a much more basic thought process, I established that our eyes TOTAL view(As in the total area) on a monitor or rather as a resoloution is 32k, Granted, our eyes dont see in a perfect rectangle, nor in pixels, nor are our eyes digital, but including this information in mind while the total viewing area of our eyes maybe 32k, peripheral vision as in the area that your eye can see at one time(not the total area) would be close to 16k, because we don't see the entire 32k area, our eyes are not that big(Anime Eyes are unrealistic), so 16k TECHNICALLY, would be the resoloution of our eyes , but then i factor in what you are stating, while our eyes have a periphial vision of 16k, most of that is blured out in favour of the things your immediately focusing on, which would be close to 8k in resolution, but one needs to take into account that i have been accounting for 2 eyes, not 1 eyes, so on a more realistic level 4k is the imediate resoloution of 1 eye, 8k is the total periphial vision of one eyye and 16k is the total viewable area of one eye. In conclusion while 8k Monitors ARE starting to become a thing, there is no real need for one, a 4k 60 hertz monitor ensures you will see the most detail with very little bottlenecks, but hey, I'm keeping things unbelivably simple.

Ignoring the retina, brain, and nine+ minutes of needless blather -- the eye includes a lens system, and assuming that this lens matches the rest of the system -- you can work out the answer from simple optics.

Skipping the part about what you mean by 'resolution' -- a perfect lens with a 100 mm aperture can produce a resolution of about one arc-second. As aperture is reduced, resolution drops. For example, a 50 mm aperture has a resolution of 2 arc-seconds.

Where the human iris varies with light between 1 and 8 mm -- the resolution varies between 12 and 100 arc-seconds. On average --30 arc-seconds is a good estimate.

For an idea of what this means -- we can see something the size of Moon as a circle of about 60 pixels in diameter (the Moon is about 1,800 arc-seconds in diameter).

What is limited is the eye’s resolution: how close two objects can become before they blur into one. At absolute best, humans can resolve two lines about 0.01 degrees apart: a 0.026mm gap, 15cm from your face. In practice, objects 0.04mm wide (the width of a fine human hair) are just distinguishable by good eyes, objects 0.02mm wide are not.

So that would mean that pixels that are 0.02mm wide would be the best that you could fit in a monitor so that you couldn't notice ANY pixels. That would mean that there would be standard resolutions based on the panel size. That would mean that a 1080p panel would need to have an area of 0.02 x 2073600 (the pixels of 1080p) square mm . That would mean 4,147,200 square mm or 41.472 square cm without the bezels of the screen.

Feel free to compare if an 8mm film was created to be a highest possible resolution - it isnt unlimited but requires the vectors of lens to translate - even a screen to display on would have thread count.

As our human lens is moving FOVeally in 2d to render 3d, its more comparable to determine of resolution the FPS - which is disputeable between 80fps to 280fps. However with resolution, one can calculate what a comparable computer gpu core frequency would have to be. The answer is resolution in an X-Y format, algebraically one can calculate a simple real world simulator with multiple computers and displays and monitor the trend of when that becomes affordable based on receipt as technology doubles and halves in time.

However, I didn't see any neon colour spreading from those blue lines. Just a load of lines with a blue colour applied to those falling within a central circle, and black elsewhere, on a white background. Do I need to see a doctor?

The chart at 1:44 is surely all you need, isn't it? Just that, and your own determination of how much of, say, a 70 inch screen you can see at once from 5ft away, or how much of it plus how much extra space around it.

I'd say that chart is just about bang on, by the way, if not a little optimistic about what the typical eye can resolve. A 1080p, 70 inch touchscreen display creates some very weird moire effects on your retina when you stand touching-distance away from it, ie maybe 3ft, from the pixels and the very fine black areas separating them just starting to be resolved by the eye. Get in closer, maybe 1ft distance (so each screen pixel occupies maybe 6 sensor cells across in your eye), and the individual coloured pieces are all too obvious. Really to avoid any artefacting and too-obvious pixellation at all from super-close-up, you'd want 8k SuperHiVision at that screen size (a resolution that's estimated as being about equal to what your eye can resolve in total, or in fact far more so as you only need that rez across your central retina region, but the screen itself has to extend across your entire field of view and be ready to show full quality if you shift your focus and where your eyes are pointing at any part of itself... ie, 8k should give "retina" rez on the whole of a curved screen, within the POV angle allowed by your eyesockets without your head turning), but from any normal viewing distance 1080p is just fine, and if you wanted to use it as a digital whiteboard or other kind of interactive display, 4k would do the job.

NB, isn't the "spatial resolution" bit and the amount of light better described as lens focus, and shutter aperture?

Hey great job! I remember after researching this for VR project it was really hard for me to easily describe it to people, but you totally nailed it!

Few main points:
Our brains and our visual cortex are absolutely amazing at processing visual information.
Our eyes are less impressive if not totally terrible, and can be roughly described as two cameras:
fish lens camera with low resolution for whole 150 degrees of FOV and another camera very low angle (very zoomed in) when it's roughly 80 pixels per horizontal degree and you need that resolution for just 2 degrees in the center. But moving away from the center of vision resolution rapidly halves every 2.5 degrees away from the center.
Here relevant information presents in a way to even let you play around with numbers:

So I’ve figured it out.... If the human eye’s resolution was put in terms of a camera’s resolution, it would be roughly 256k. Here’s why. There are just under 9 megapixels in 4k resolution. The human eye’s resolution uses 576 megapixels. If you multiply 9 (4k’s megapixels rounded up) by 64, you will get 576. Multiply 4 (4K) by the same thing and you get 256k as the human eye’s resolution.

Go outside on a clear night, close one eye, and with your other eye look up at a star (not at a planet).  The star you see will appear as a bright dot and will have a small but perceptible size.  However, we know that this star is much too far away for our eye to tell the star's actual size. Rather, the size of the bright dot you see is caused by a photo receptor in your eye firing in response to the light of the star hitting the receptor.  It is the size of the light receptor in your eye that you see, not the size of the actual star.  The size of the bright dot tells you the resolution of your eye.

2:32 "Because a camera snaps an entire frame at once." Actually, with the way video compression works, if new data in the image is needed, it's captured. But if you have a stationary background, the camera only captures that background once, and then just puts whatever's moving in front of it. And even then, if something is moving without changing, it will just move that block of pixels overtime without creating new data. So cameras don't actually capture a full image.

It could be that after we die everything does indeed cease to exist. If you've ever experienced a concussion or have fallen to sleep only to be woken up with the sense that you never actually fell to sleep, that you were essentially robbed of those hours of rest, then you'll know what I'm talking about.

If, after I die, the only consciousness I have to perceive existence is gone then to me there would be no difference between the loss of consciousness and the end of the universe. The same is true for you, if conscious experience does indeed end.

For this reason I find that ending a plot by killing the viewpoint character or characters is a cheap means to an end, it would do just as well to suck the entire universe into a black hole to end your movie and say, "Everybody's dead!"

I absolutely love Darren Aronofsky's Requiem For A Dream but I loathe his Black Swan for this very reason. Falling action in a story brings in an acceptable amount of irresolution.

Horror authors Edgar Allen Poe and H.P. Lovecraft often didn't understand this principle and, for shock value, would end on a punchline the same way a joke does. I can't help but laugh when this happens no matter how horrifying the tale. I laughed at the end of Black Swan for the same reason---not because I'm irreverent, but because it's structured the same way a joke is. A joke with action after the punchline has been delivered is no longer funny.

Poe's Black Cat is my favorite story of his for sheer visceral disgust and horror---it's very well written. Except for the end, which says, "I had walled the monster up within the tomb!" What sort of ending is that? The viewpoint character isn't dead, but once the big question is resolved it's like Poe just quit, there is no acceptable falling action and I can't help but hear a 'Badum ching!!" as though Poe were telling a bad joke at a comedy club. The Tell-Tale Heart is similar in its ending.

But his Cask of Amontillado is perhaps my favorite just in terms of form. Here's the ending to that, "For the half a century no mortal has disturbed them. In pace requiescat!" Now that's an ending. It brings acceptable, rather than unacceptable, irresolution. It goes beyond answering the main question, "How is the viewpoint character going to get vengeance and will they succeed."

I like H. P. Lovecraft's "The Music Of Erich Zann" best of all because of the fairy tale like quality the story brings us into an absurd universe and then transports us back into the "real" world in the same manner. It is quite unlike his other work and I wonder if he was even the original author.

Acceptable irresolution of a story takes us a step beyond the main conceit and leaves it behind creating a trail of new and unanswered, but not main, questions. Falling action in The Black Cat and Telltale Heart would see the viewpoint characters being taken into custody (or resisting arrest or any of an infinite number of other things) and those trails don't have to be resolved because the main draw of the story, or joke, has been understood and resolved. An amount of irresolution is always needed. Which is why existence on this plane is so maddening and understood to be a joke. There is no trail, presumably, no acceptable irresolution taking us into the future. Just one, bad, resolution and the joke is forgotten.

People don't have photographic memories, because our brain and mind is more akin to cpu+hard drive+Operating system. Our memories while mostly forming in a graphical format are in a sense the same as a digital image file; that's created by the firing of neurons in your mind; digital Information on your computer is created and stored by firing electric energy through a path of resistors and transistors, your brain creates the information of your mind (consciousness, spirit, self thought, inner self) by firing energy through through a system of neural pathways that allow the concept of self thought, memory, and images to be created and stored in a very fragment form.

This is why it is necessary to sleep, and also why it is a good practice to nap after studying . Dreams are an amalgamation of several thousands of different memory sequences, while you are dreaming your brain is processing a great deal of data and organizing it, removing broken memories (memories that are corrupted and unreadable) and organizing knowledge.

In a sense, your subconscious is your automatic brain, and your conscious is your self controlled brain. When you sleep; your conscious self is in line with your subconscious mind which allows you (your brain) to see everything it needs to organize in a graphical representation of your current self world.

So; what you see with your eyes, is recreated in your brain via neural bursts of energy and chemical sensations, and stored in areas of your brain for later use, your brain then slips into sleep mode, and runs a defrag in order to optimize memory and knowledge, removing useless memories that it no longer needs, and reorganizing your knowledge and thoughts from prior days as either destroy or file.

if you were able to quantify that fragmented data and create a digital image format of it, much of the information would look like of a huge impossible puzzle; it take someone probably (my best guess) 30 years to put all that information into an actually decipherable visual form.


Now that brings me to my final thought on this Vsauce episode from way back when the difference in the architecture of your brain and the architecture of your computer is your brain runs on a data system of (around my best guess) 10 > 1000+ on a quantum scale and your computer runs a binary system of 0>100 on a binary scale.

and that's my bullshit science for you; sources are "Discovery magazine, Popular Science, and Time Magazines pieces on your brain vs your computer, Discovery Specials, and old curiosity like shows from the 90's.

Information is highly outdated, and often used and misunderstood, but offers the best analogy between the mind of the human and the mind of a computer.

We can see words that aren't there, because the true word looks similar to the one our brain finds more common in itself. Another interesting thing about vision is that we don't really understand the world based on our visual field. There's a 2nd subconscious vision system that puts invisible labels on everything so we know what we're looking at without having to consciously analyze the size, shape and orientation of objects. In fact, you can have a stroke that knocks those areas out and although your visual cortex is intact and you can see as well as ever, you can't figure out what you're looking at- at least not without considerable time and effort. You can also have your visual cortex knocked out and although you're in total darkness, you can still feel when objects are passed in front of you.

I had all of these specific questions circling around in my mind during film production class so, logically, I asked my professor. Unable to give me a definitive answer my professor challenged me to find out and return to our next lecture with the answer, he suggested that my best bet would be asking a digital engineering expert. So after tracking down and scheduling an appointment to meet, the digital engineering expert I'd met up with at a local production company was disappointed to inform me that he did not know the answer. At the conclusion of our meeting the expert referred me to and set me up an appointment with his friend, who also happened to be an optometrist, in order to get to the bottom of this question. With dwindling hope I met with the optometrist during his lunch break, but once again I was told that he could not answer my question.
On the day of my next film production lecture I felt like a complete let down for having to run all around town, yet still failing to discover an answer that I could report back to my class and professor. With just about fifteen minutes remaining before class I made a last ditch effort by scouring YouTube, which then led me to watching this Vsauce video. As soon as class commenced my professor instantly put me on the spot about whether or not I followed through on finding an answer to my question. At this opportunity I stood up and gave a presentation for the entire hour and thirty minutes by reenacting the entire lesson this video imparted upon me, along with a lot of bullshitting about the hard work and research that went into me concluding this information.
So all-in-all I appreciate the fact that I have the ability to ponder such vague and complex questions, but after a few search inquiries I can come across a short video that explains everything I wanted to know with relatively no effort.
Good ol' technology :)

Blu-ray, it's resolution is 1920 x 1080 NOT 1280 x 720 and it's specification limits the frame rate to 24 FPS. None of those things describe resolution. Resolution is the number of pixels within a display or image sensor. That's it. The size of the sensor has nothing to do with resolution, but it does have something to do with a "cropping" factor as well as how sensitive it is to light (a larger sensor with the same resolution as a smaller sensor will be more sensitive to light). Amount of light is not a determining factor in resolution, nor is what the millions of pixels are encoding, and how close the subject is also has nothing to do with resolution either... (unless you are speaking in terms of the discernible detail of the subject within the shot , in that case, the closer the subject is, the more detail you'll be able to see, but the less of the entire subject you'll be able to see as well). Finally, you said something true; that at a far enough distance, the detail between different resolutions become indiscernible. Beyond that, you speak of things for which I know nothing about. I really don't understand why you said some of those things though, because they simply are not true. I must be missing something.

Great video as always! One key idea left undisclosed that I wanted to cover was this:

Suppose you want to capture a single spherical 360° snapshot photo and preview it using a virtual reality headset that has a pixel density so high that you can’t distinguish the pixels from each other. The pixel density of that ideal headset covering your entire field of vision was discussed already on this video (approx. 576 megapixels). But how many pixels would that spherical photo need to have?

This is actually relatively simple mathematics. Let’s use those Roger N. Clark’s calculations as a starting point. He calculated the pixel spacing of the human visual acuity to be 0.3 arc-minutes. Since one full circle contains 360 degrees and each degree contains 60 arc minutes, we can calculate that one full circle of pixels contains 360*60/0.3 = 72 000 pixels. From this figure, we can now calculate the surface area of the sphere. The (theoretical) radius of this sphere is 72 000 pixels / (2 * π), so the surface area is 4 * π * (72 000 pixels / (2 * π)) ². This gives us a grand total of 1 650 118 450 pixels, or 1 650 megapixels. There’s our answer!

In those 1 650 megapixels of image data, we would probably reserve one byte (eight bits) of information for each three color channels (red, green & blue), so one raw photo would eat up 4,95 gigabytes of disk space. Almost 5 gigabytes, and that’s just one spherical picture. Suppose you wanted to capture video with this standard, at least 60 frames per second would seem like the way to go. That’s 297 gigabytes of information per second.

Now think about it: it would require this enormous amount of data just to store one single fleeting moment in time, from a single point in space. Meanwhile, you’re surrounded by data like this around you all the time. It’s just, I’d say it really gives you… perspective.

Thank you, Vsauce (sorry: don't know your real name). I am just wondering: how many microns is the smallest object that the unassisted human eye can see? You describe the resolution of the eye in camera terms only. On the beach last month (August), I noticed that the dry sand sparkled in the Sun, when the Sun is at about 20°-30° high in the sky and viewed from a certain obtuse angle towards the Sun. I got my pocket microscope out and saw tiny crystals of orange silicates, grey limestones shards, and the clear quartz "gemstones" that was refracting the sunlight causing the sparkles. Quite beautiful in the microscope. The smallest sand particles are said to be about 600 microns small (600/1000th of a mm or 2/3 mm), and I could easily resolve them with my very sharp eyes unassisted. Maybe one micron is too small for any human eye to see? So somewhere between 1-600 microns? Hope that this is an interesting question. Thank you. Agape. Andrew

The broadest is the macula lutea, which contains the perifovea, which surrounds the parafovea, which surrounds the fovea, which contains the foveola, which contains the umbo. So, after watching the video video and this one, I have another question?  Is there lag to our visual perception?  The hanging second on the clock made me ponder this.  You stated that the blurred images are truncated by our brain and the final image is then inserted where the blur is... This leads me to think that since you didn't see the image until you did, there would have to be processing lag to perceive the missing blur as the final image.

So how much lag do we have between the actual seen event and us perceiving it?
It would also seem that other senses may be lagged or timed to match, right?  If I look at myself snapping my fingers I see and hear the event at the same time, is the lag the same between the senses or does the brain play another chemical trick to reconcile them together?

So the megapixel equivalent numbers below refer to the spatial detail in an image that would be required to show what the human eye could see when you view a scene. 90 degrees * 60 arc-minutes/degree * 1/0.3 * 90 * 60 * 1/0.3 = 324,000,000 pixels (324 megapixels). 120 * 120 * 60 * 60 / (0.3 * 0.3) = 576 megapixels

Orson Scott Card addresses the "The End" of life in his Introduction of Speaker for the Dead. In it, he addresses that during funerals people like to either sum up the deceased's life either as a sequence of all their failures, or as a near-deified version of the deceased's life. Usually the latter. He set out in writing his book, Speaker for the Dead, with the idea that during the final end of a person's life, the only true way to give that person a perfect resolution, a perfect story, is by telling the whole story, all the triumphs, all the failures, all the times of piece, all the inner struggles and strife and conflict and yet all the beauty and little moments of perfection that ultimately culminated in that person's complete life. Their complete story. So, in an essence, only through true looks at a person's complete story at the final end of their existance can anyone around them fully realize the size and scope and beauty of the film that would be their life.

Films such as "Jobs" and "The Social Network" (though not so much on the latter seeing as how the subject isn't exactly dead!) have done a pretty decent job at looking at both the inner vision and the inner demons of their subjects. So far as films go, I think that's about as close as anyone's really going to get to doing a true "Speaking" for the dead.

Really, it's comparing apples to oranges. Sure you can talk about what the eye can do optically and biologically. But as Vsauce explained, that's not really what we "see", we see the processed image in our visual cortex, which is in a data format completely alien to what is stored on digital devices. In our brain it's an analog stream of symbolic information based both on input from the retina and experiences stored in our memory. We don't eve get one complete full image at a time from the retina like individual frames from a video camera. Each rod & cone cell is individually sending signals asynchronously.

Couple that with the wide range of variation from person to person of how well they can focus an image and how developed their visual cortexes are at processing images. You just plain can't put a number on the subject.
What shape is our Field of view?

If it were done properly it would really help rendering images go more smoothly and it could even be set up for multiple people.

The video takes a long time to get to the answer but it explains a lot of interesting things along the way. For those of you that want the quick answer, its 8 mpx instantaneous constructed up to 576 mpx raw information over time. The brain also does many things that simple imagers don't such as records 3d, motion information, and changes in scene over time. So the visual information the brain is dealing with is probably more like simultaneously considering a multi gigapixel movie. But it also compresses this information and extracts out essential features which may well mean much less information actually being handled.

Great video but it makes me wonder what is in store for the TV market.  For example, when I look at a 4K TV that is smaller in size I can't tell the difference between 4K and 1080P.  However, when you get to a 55 inch screen or bigger you can definitely tell the difference as I can make out the square pixels on the screen on 1080P but 4K I really can't.  Selfishly, what I really want to know is on the average screen at what resolution will I no longer be able to tell the difference?  Would that be , 6K, 8K, or 12K?  There has to be a limit at which adding pixels makes zero difference say in a big screen TV 55 to 85 inches.  Maybe we are already there with 4K but I have no frame of reference higher than that.

Your size in 4D
Every single cell inside your body as an adult is foreign to what was your body as a kid. So your adult body has absolutely nothing to do with your body as a kid.
So here's the thought experiment:
Let's suppose someone were to be born inside a room twice their size and live there for 20 years never having left the room once.

Nothing that leave's the body leaves the room. No shed skin, no haircuts, no exhale, waste, urine, tears, nothing. All necessary food, air, and water come in through a feeding tube, and all exhale remains.

How much of each element would be in the room to keep an average man alive throughout their lifetime.

In other words how many pounds of each element would the average human have accumulated by age 80?

Each eye may have 1+7M "sensors", but it only has about 1M distinct nerves coming out. No matter how hard you try, you can never see more than 1M distinct pixels at the same time... and actually even less than that.

Another way of seeing it: you can detect changes in "1+7M different positions", but you can only detect less than 1M changes at once.

Interesting fact:  The average person blinks about 15,000 times in a day.  As crazy as it sounds.  Each blink is about 0.15 seconds.  Which means your eyes are closed because of blinks for about 2250 seconds or about 37.5 minutes a day. 
And in the whole year, your eyes are closed for about 228 hours because of blinking.  Or just over 9 days on average.

How many images can an average computer monitor display? Clearly there are only a finite number of pixels, and a finite number of states they could be in, so there should be a (very large) finite number of images. But, the cool part is that this would include not only every picture ever taken or document typed, but every one not taken or typed, or cooler, not yet taken or typed. Could a program be written for this? While there would obviously be a greater number of false or abstract pictures, there is a practical application. If we restrict the program to every possible text document, or blueprint, we would get instructions for every invention ever to exist and an explanation of their operating principles, every mathematical proof possible, and every building that could be built. Again, we would also have a (nearly) infinite number of incorrect proofs and unstable buildings and broken inventions, but programs exist today that can filter those out. Interesting fact:  The average person blinks about 15,000 times in a day.  As crazy as it sounds.  Each blink is about 0.15 seconds.  Which means your eyes are closed because of blinks for about 2250 seconds or about 37.5 minutes a day. 
And in the whole year, your eyes are closed for about 228 hours because of blinking.  Or just over 9 days on average.
If you like fun facts and have some free time, I make videos over the facts that most people missed.  Have a good one.!

So, what this all boils down to is that 1080p is a fine standard if the display is small enough, like for most PCs. But given a larger display, say 60 inches at 5 feet away, 4k resolutions becomes necessary to overcome the human eye's ability to perceive that resolution. Film doesn't have to worry about resolution because it uses light, which is smaller than any perceivable resolution, assuming the material/negative can support that display.

Since the objective is to match the Nyquist frequency and use the eye as an automatic form of anti-alias, it's a safe assumption at this point in technological advancement to allow for accurate "jaggies" in tesselation on graphics processors.

Now, the only thing to overcome is the limited color range that current RGB technologies support, and maybe to increase channel depth from 1 byte per color channel to 2 bytes per color channel.

I watched this video, idk, about a week ago, and since then, I've thought about it a lot. And, there's one very nerdy question I have in regards to something that ties in with this.
You mentioned, and I've heard before, that the brain tends to "fill in" a lot of the spaces in your vision with previous knowledge of it's surroundings. Well... What if there was no previous knowledge?
Say, someone invented a teleporter that could teleport you anywhere you wanted to go... How would your brain respond when you got there? (For this example, we're presuming that the teleporter works both absolutely accurately, so no worries about "mistranslation errors", and instantaneously). Would you, for a moment, only be able to see a small cone directly in front of you? Would your brain fill in the missing information with random data (perhaps causing kind of a visual "static")?
My guess is that you would just feel extremely disoriented for a moment, and your vision would be extremely blurry for a few seconds, until the brain gathered enough information to put together an actual image... But, maybe there's something I'm missing, and even if not, it just seems like an interesting question... That is, of course, unanswerable until we actually make a teleporter. lol

BUT, a point missed here is retinal processing. In the fovea, photoreceptors are crammed close together. However, the resolution of these light receptors - if they were pixels - would still give poorish vision, probably about the minimum driving standard of 6/12. The reason that retinal cones give better than mathematically expected resolution is due to interneuronal processing. You get effects like edge enhancement using summation and suppression of adjacent receptors. Nystagmus (trembling) comes into play and is reminiscent of digital "dithering" which improves audio resolution.

For example, I was talking with my friends one day, and one of my friends said something, to which all of us laughed, and then my friend turned and kicked me and called me a certain racial stereotype. After this, I stopped in my tracks, having a conscience of consciousness moment, ( Where you realize that you are a human being, with a mind and free will, these often come when you stare at an empty wall for too long.) I don't know what this is all about, but I think it comes from my brain taking all of it's past experiences and compiling them into a logically probable "prediction" for lack of a better word, of what the day to come will be like, as I noticed that these come most often after a monotonous, boring day. Please tell me what you think.
All the best,
-Kyle.

Few years ago, while I was travelling by train, I posed myself this question. I was at the bottom of the train and assumed that looking at the railroad there was a distance where the two parallel lines were fused into one. So when we passed a big tree I just counted how many seconds I needed to percieve this impression. In this case I approximately calculated the speed, the width of railroad and my rough conclusion was that to represent a "fovea resolution" image (considering also that a monitor is normally involving 1/3 of the view field an not more) was from 4000 to 6000 pixel in width. Please consider also that I am short sighted, but I was wearing glasses.

I think we view things In a singular pixel.  The addition of multiple pixels may only limit our expectations as to what we perceive visually  and/or  actually over encumbering our visual perceptions through our physical receptors. There for we may only be taking tiny images, placing them next to each other to create a different image to make it seem more resolved. I believe that the actual "pixelization" (I realize it isn't actually a word) of our sight is more subliminal and conscious based than physically creatable or  or even remotely possible to mimic to an exact "t" of sorts.  I am not claiming this as the truth or even claiming to be more intelligent than any other person,  I have practically a miniscule amount of knowledge pertaining to the human eye. Mega from megapixels stands for a million, so there are actually 576 times a million pixels. 576 million = 576,000,000 pixels. Full HD = 1920 x 1080 pixels = 2,073,600 pixels and Ultra HD = 3840 x 2160 pixels = 8,294,400 pixels. So if we had to express the pixels we can see, the resolution would be (in 16:9 widescreen): 32000 x 18000 pixels. This is the resolution of the eye.

@timothy strother Not exactly... When you look at something to your left with your right eye, and vice versa, you will see your nose. However, when you look at something to your left with both eyes, your brain prioritizes the picture from the left eye and it "overlaps" the picture from your right eye and your nose is processed out of the composite picture.

You're just seeing your nose cause you want to. Don't think about it and 2 days later, when you'll have forgotten this video ever existed, you'll be able to un-see it.

I have a really interesting question the other day

We all know how pixel work, right? Each pixel is either red, green, or blue, and the make up of all these pixel is what lets us see everything we see on out our computer screens or tvs. Every picture is just a different combination of RGB.

Now lets say we had a 1080p screen, and we had it rotate through every possible RGB combination for every pixel. Would we see....everything? The past? The future? Hitler wearing a clown nose, and from every angle? Sure it might take a billion years but someone ought to be doing this now right?

Would it not make sense to say that the resolution of the eye, while still debatable by what field of vision you choose to define, can be determined by the measure of the calculated 2D plane of molecules?
Pending the distance from you, whatever the focal point of measure, nothing in-front or behind the chosen point is accounted for, and that is your 2D measuring 'canvas'. From there, it's just a matter of calculating how many molecules (also pending: what base molecule you measure with) across and how many molecules vertical your vision accommodates (at that distance).

Another optical illusion that I managed to create a few times while taking a bath, was the following: 
Fix your vision on a very specific point, say a handle or whatever point there is. Dont stress yourself, just relax and keep staring, do not move your eyes in the slightest, but its normal if they start to close a bit. Sooner or later the image will start to fade away, and whenever you move your eyes slightly (at that point it almost has to happen as the point you were fixated on also faded away) you will suddenly see very strong outlines between any 2 surfaces with significant color difference, similar to a sharpening effect used in image editing programs, and TVs. 
Basically the entire field of view gets so still that the brain tries to filter out everything that stands still, much like it filters out glasses, hair or your nose, which are also just fixed things in your view. That filtering basicaly works by putting a negative of the image you see over your perceptive view so they cancel each other out. But when you slightly move your eyes the image you see and the negative that is supposed to cancel it out dont match anymore and you see these outlines around stuff, because along those outlines the colors dont cancel each other out but instead even add up, while, if you really moved your eyes slightly, the larger surfaces remain largely invisible.

I hate to nit pick, but most of your media resolutions are dead wrong - the only one that's close to right is DVD, and it's a very important difference when looking at stored resolution:
- Neither VHS nor Laser disc have a pixel resolution, and both store NTSC/PAL frame size, with 575/675 raster lines per frame.  Analog raster lines don't equate very well to digital pixels.
- DVD's pixels are non-square, are actually at the broadcast standard of 720 x 486 px for NTSC and 720 x 576 for PAL; when Pixel Aspect Ratio is accounted for, DVDs have an equivalent resolution of 648 x 486 (NTSC 4:3), 864 x 486 (NTSC 16:9), 768 x 576 (PAL 4:3) and 1024 x 576 (PAL 16:9).
- Nearly every cinematic Blu-ray ever produced stores a 1920x1080 frame; the only ones that store a 1280 x 720 image are those sourced from television where 720p is the original source frame size.
- Digital IMAX theaters project at either 2K or 4K - IMAX film has no digital equivalent resolution.

Neat episode! So resolution is defined as the smallest distance that two points are distinguishable from each other. In this definition, the smaller that distance is, the better the resolution. Then technically, hi-res is a bad thing. You want something that is high pixel density, not hi-res. If you're referring to resolution as the size, say 2560×1440, it still depends on the size of the picture, ie. pixel density.
